subcourses.name: Basic Math
subcourses.description: Introduction to basic arithmetic operations and number theory.

lessonPlan.title: Introduction to Numbers
lessonPlan.description: Learn about whole numbers, place value, and how to use the number line.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the place value of 5 in 352?
Is 0 a whole number? (yes or no)

contentParagraphs: Whole numbers are numbers without fractions or decimals, starting from 0 and increasing by 1 each time (0, 1, 2, 3, ...).
Place value tells us the value of each digit in a number based on its position. For example, in 352, the 5 is in the tens place, so it represents 50.
The number line is a visual way to show numbers in order. It helps you understand counting, comparing, and the concept of greater and less than.

lessonPlan.title: Basic Operations
lessonPlan.description: Master the four basic operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
contentParagraphs: Addition means putting numbers together to find the total. Subtraction means taking away from a number.
Multiplication is repeated addition. For example, 4 × 3 means 4 added three times (4 + 4 + 4 = 12).
Division is splitting a number into equal parts. For example, 12 ÷ 3 means splitting 12 into 3 equal groups of 4.

lessonPlan.title: Factors and Multiples
lessonPlan.description: Understand how to find factors, multiples, and identify prime numbers.

practiceQuestions.question: What are the factors of 12? (comma separated)
Is 7 a prime number? (yes or no)
What is the first multiple of 5 after 10?

contentParagraphs: A factor is a number that divides another number exactly. For example, 3 is a factor of 12 because 12 ÷ 3 = 4.
A multiple is the result of multiplying a number by an integer. For example, multiples of 5 are 5, 10, 15, 20, ...
Prime numbers are numbers greater than 1 that have only two factors: 1 and themselves.

lessonPlan.title: Fractions & Decimals
lessonPlan.description: Learn about fractions, equivalent fractions, and how decimals relate to fractions.
contentParagraphs: A fraction represents a part of a whole. The top number is the numerator, and the bottom is the denominator.
Equivalent fractions are different fractions that represent the same value, like 1/2 and 2/4.
Decimals are another way to show parts of a whole, using a decimal point. For example, 0.5 is the same as 1/2.

subcourses.name: Pre-Algebra
subcourses.description: Prepare for algebra with foundational concepts and skills.

lessonPlan.title: Integers and Rational Numbers
lessonPlan.description: Learn about integers, rational numbers, and how to compare and order them.

practiceQuestions.question: Is 3/4 a rational number? (yes or no)

contentParagraphs: Integers are whole numbers and their opposites, including zero. They can be positive, negative, or zero. Understanding how to work with integers is a key skill in pre-algebra.
Rational numbers are numbers that can be written as a fraction of two integers. This includes integers, fractions, and terminating or repeating decimals.
Comparing and ordering integers and rational numbers helps you understand their relationships and how they fit on the number line.

lessonPlan.title: Exponents and Radicals
lessonPlan.description: Explore the basics of exponents and radicals, including how to simplify them.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the square root of 49?

contentParagraphs: Exponents are a way to represent repeated multiplication. For example, 2^3 means 2 × 2 × 2 = 8.
Radicals, such as square roots, are the opposite of exponents. The square root of a number is a value that, when multiplied by itself, gives the original number.
Simplifying radicals means finding the simplest form of a root, such as reducing √16 to 4.

lessonPlan.title: Algebraic Expressions
lessonPlan.description: Learn how to work with algebraic expressions, including evaluating and simplifying them.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the variable in the expression 5y + 2?

contentParagraphs: Algebraic expressions are combinations of variables, numbers, and operations. Variables are symbols that represent unknown values.
Evaluating expressions means substituting values for variables and performing the operations. Combining like terms involves adding or subtracting terms that have the same variable part.

lessonPlan.title: Equations and Inequalities
lessonPlan.description: Understand how to solve simple equations and inequalities, and apply them to real-world problems.

practiceQuestions.question: Is x = 3 a solution to the inequality x > 2? (yes or no)

contentParagraphs: Equations are statements that two expressions are equal. Solving equations means finding the value of the variable that makes the equation true.
Inequalities show that one expression is greater or less than another. Solving inequalities means finding all values that make the inequality true.
These concepts are used in real-world applications, such as budgeting, measuring, and comparing quantities.

subcourses.name: Algebra
subcourses.description: Learn the fundamentals of algebra including variables, equations, and functions.

lessonPlan.title: Introduction to Algebra
lessonPlan.description: Learn the fundamental building blocks of algebra and how to work with mathematical expressions.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is a variable in the expression 3x + 5?
What is the value of the constant in the expression 7y - 4?

contentParagraphs: Algebra is the study of mathematical symbols and the rules for manipulating these symbols. In this section, you will learn about variables, constants, and how to form and simplify mathematical expressions. Variables are symbols (often letters) that represent unknown values. Constants are fixed values that do not change.

Mathematical expressions combine variables, constants, and operations (like addition and multiplication) to represent relationships. Understanding how to read and write these expressions is the foundation of algebra.

The order of operations (PEMDAS) is crucial for solving problems correctly. The order of operations (Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division, Addition/Subtraction) tells you the correct sequence to solve expressions, ensuring everyone gets the same answer.

lessonPlan.title: Linear Equations
lessonPlan.description: Master the art of solving linear equations and representing them graphically.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the slope of the line y = 4x + 1?
If y = 2x and x = 5, what is y?

contentParagraphs: Linear equations are equations between two variables that produce a straight line when graphed. You will learn to solve simple equations, tackle word problems, and graph lines on the coordinate plane.
A linear equation is an equation of the form ax + b = c, where x is the variable. Solving these equations means finding the value of x that makes the equation true.
Word problems help you translate real-life situations into equations. Graphing lines shows how solutions relate visually, and helps you understand slope and intercepts.

lessonPlan.title: Polynomials
lessonPlan.description: Explore polynomial operations and techniques for factoring complex expressions.
contentParagraphs: Polynomials are expressions consisting of variables and coefficients, combined using addition, subtraction, and multiplication. This section covers adding, subtracting, multiplying, and factoring polynomials, which are foundational for higher-level math.
Adding and subtracting polynomials involves combining like terms. Multiplying polynomials uses the distributive property and can involve special products like the square of a binomial.
Factoring is the process of writing a polynomial as a product of simpler polynomials, which is useful for solving equations and simplifying expressions.

lessonPlan.title: Quadratic Equations
lessonPlan.description: Dive deep into quadratic equations and their real-world applications.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the vertex of y = (x - 1)^2 + 3?
Which method can be used to solve any quadratic equation?

contentParagraphs: Quadratic equations are second-degree equations that can be solved by various methods. You will explore their standard form, different solving techniques, and real-world applications.
A quadratic equation has the form ax^2 + bx + c = 0. You can solve quadratics by factoring, completing the square, or using the quadratic formula. The graph of a quadratic is a parabola.
Quadratic equations appear in many real-world problems, such as projectile motion and area optimization. Understanding their properties helps you model and solve complex scenarios.
